channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Seeking Senior Perl Developers for Global Domination
item.description: Our client is an international IT company managing over 4 million domains for retail and corporate customers in 200 countries. Hold up—200 countries? Talk about reach! To help achieve global domination, they’re looking for a few top-notch senior Perl developers whose experience with implementing APIs and protocols is only matched by their drive to design and develop domain software solutions.

item.title: Your mission, should you choose to accept it . . .
item.description: The client bankrolling this exciting new mission is one of the UK’s leading estate agencies. With over 60 branches, they’ve got eyes everywhere. Their website is on fire, and that’s where you come in: they’re looking for a senior-level Perl programmer who is never shaken nor stirred, no matter the situation. If Modern Perl fits like a calfskin glove then this might be the role for you.

item.title: Paging Dr. Perl
item.description: This organization is one of the world’s leading developers of medical diagnostic technologies and clinical software. They believe in security, wellness, and the importance of driving innovation to deliver patient benefit. You won’t be in a white coat, but it’s better than that—your work will be used by the NHS, research labs, and healthcare providers worldwide.

item.title: The Cool Stuff You Wish They Taught in School. London based Perl Telecommute
item.description: Our client is a leading online tech publication with more than 40 millions readers worldwide. Their articles cover electronics, hardware, software, AI, space, cloud services, and culture. They know what’s hot in the world of computers, and they tell the world all about it in crisp, engaging articles.

item.title: Frankenstein’s Monster is Just Misunderstood! Perl in Australia
item.description: This client’s mission involves developing cost-efficient genotyping technology and promoting the development of crops adapted to suit their environment. They care about doing great things, and they want their team to be as happy as the crops they breed.

item.description: Roger presented different approaches to each task. Must Read.

item.description: Check out this mix of Perl and Raku solutions.

item.description: Thoroughly discussed the task in great detail.

item.description: Nice and simple solution to the Smallest Positive Number task.

item.description: Myoungjin has another blog post with Raku gems.

item.description: Creative blog post award must go to Colin. Always pleasure to read.

item.description: Arne once again came up with cool Perl and Raku solutions.

item.description: Interesting discussion with regard to the task "Smallest Positive Number".

item.description: Raku Solutions Review of tasks "Set Bit Count" and "Trapped Rain Water" by Andrew Shitov.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 080
item.description: Nice to see Adam back to regular blogging. It is always a pleasure to read his posts.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 080
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Smallest Positive Number" and "Count Candies" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 081
item.description: Welcome to a new week with couple of fun tasks "Common Base String" and "Frequency Sort". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read FAQ page.

item.title: PDF::Reuse - deep diving in the past
item.description: Nice use of PDF::Reuse.

item.description: Handy tips to align master.

item.description: Interesting way to figure out the area of a triangle.

item.description: Finally completed one year of daily posting on ETOOBUSY.

item.title: An update to quenv
item.description: Short blog post about quenv - quick environment

item.title: Applying Operators to Coderefs
item.description: Cool example showing how operators can be applied to coderefs by Toby.

item.title: Where do you like bugs reported?
item.description: Lady Aleena started a very interesting discussion. Please check it out and share your views.

item.title: Monthly Report - September
item.description: I have been publishing monthly reports for years now. It has become a ritual for me. I enjoy writing my monthly reports.

item.title: The Tau Station Kickstarter has gone live! (Oops)
item.description: Curtis shared a blog post about Tau Station, the world's first Biblio-RPG.

item.title: Blogs
item.description: Number of posts last week: BPO: 9; DevTo: 7; Perl.com: 1; PerlAcademy: 2; PerlHacks: 0; PerlMaven: 0; Reddit: 23; TPF: 2;

item.title: CPAN uploads
item.description: Last week there were a total of 216 uploads to CPAN of 152 distinct distributions by 79 different authors. Number of distributions with link to VCS: 126. Number of distros with CI: 69.

item.title: Optimize Perl CI/CD pipelines for Github Actions using ActiveState's Platform
item.description: Do you use CI/CD for your Perl projects? Most Perl applications were written long before CI/CD became a best practice, but it’s vital for speeding up code delivery. Learn how GitHub actions and ActiveState tooling can improve consistency, reliability and build speeds.

item.title: #480 - Hacktoberfest 2020
item.description:
Hi there

I am sure you have all already started contributing towards Hacktoberfest 2020. I have noticed lots of positive noise about the event. If you haven't joined already then please don't waste any more time and join the event. If you are looking for opensource projects to work on then please check out the list prepared by perl.com.

Have you checked out the latest interview with Damian Conway? It's part of perl.com's monthly interview series. I have already started working on the next interview with another Perl Ambassador. Please keep watching this space.

Curtis Poe shared the Kickstarter for Tau Station - The MMO BIBLIO-RPG.

Last but not least, please take care of yourself and your family. Enjoy the rest of the newsletter.
